data.name: Deduce interface id by EUI-64
data.description:
EUI-64 is a common method to generate an interface id for the local-link IPv6 addresses.

An Ethernet 48-bit MAC address is a combination of a 24-bit Organizational Unique Identifier (OUI) and a 24-bit device identifier, written in hexadecimal.

The modified EUI-64 takes 48-bit MAC address as input, insert `fffe` between the OUI and device identifier, then invert the U/L bit, which is the bit 1 of the highest byte of the MAC address.

The process would be:

```
00:50:3e:12:34:56         # sample mac address
00:50:3e:ff:fe:12:34:56   # insert ff:fe
02:50:3e:ff:fe:12:34:56   # invert bit 1 of the highest byte
```

Normally IPv6 address is represented in group of 16 bits (called hextet), so the final interface id should look like `0250:3eff:fe12:3456`.

Write a function which takes a string representation of a MAC address, and returns the interface id generated using the EUI-64 method.

**Note**: all hexadecimal characters should be in lower case.
